bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 5, 1901

div1.p: Reed considers Durham's work on a bacillus. Although there is no work for the Yellow Fever Board in Cuba at present, he advises Kean to maintain Camp Lazear. Reed discusses immunization against yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 5, 1901

opener.dateline:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
June 5, 1901.

div1.p:
There
are two good fellows
to whom I desire to
write a line, to wit:
the Commandante of all
the Charitable Institu-
tions on “The Pearl” and
the Isle of Pines, and the
chief Sanitarian of the
City of Havana- Un-
fortunately, night before
last, in trying to make
two window-sash pass
2
each other, my right thumb
got in the way, & also,
got a dreadful contusion
which interferes very
much with my ability
to write- Yours, most
noble Señor, of May 27th,
just “after the ball was
over”, came a few days
ago; and if I should follow
my own inclinations,
I should start down South
before the months is over-
Durham, you know, has
come to town, & we (the
I.G., D. & myself-) have had
two long interviews.
3
The upshot seems to be
that as there is no fever
in Havana, or at least
none reported, there is
nothing to work upon at
present- As for Durham's
bacillus, we find that he
has never cultivated it,
and can't find out very much
from him about it- He
accepts our observations
as conclusive, and I am sure
that, had he received our
last Report earlier, he
would have not published
anything about his anae-
robe- Just now, the S. G-
who leaves for Manila, June
15th, has directed me to
submit a Report by Septr
4
15th, embodying the results
of our work in Cuba, so
that he can put it in his
last annual Report--
I do not share, Commandante
Bueno, your hopefulness con-
cerning finding some immu-
nizing method- Protection
& Prevention are far, far
more important. The funda-
mental facts have been
established -- the others are
of secondary importance.
Hold on to Camp Lazear a
while longer- Give my
love to your dear wife
& thank her so much for the
offer of the room- Kiss Mar-
tha & T. Jefferson- Drink one
to my health-
